output.rationale: This is an original epidemiological study examining the association between PM2.5 (and PM10) and respiratory hospital admissions using distributed lag non-linear models, which is a time-series approach. The study reports quantitative risk estimates for respiratory diseases (asthma and COPD) and appears to include effect measures with statistical significance testing. While the study focuses on comparing pre- and post-COVID-19 periods, it still meets the core inclusion criteria of examining PM2.5-respiratory hospitalization associations with appropriate study design and effect estimates.

This study meets most inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure and asthma ED visits using what appears to be a time-series design (mixed-effects quasi-Poisson regression with daily data). However, the abstract does not explicitly report a quantitative effect estimate (RR, OR, or equivalent) with confidence interval, which is a critical inclusion criterion. While the study found a significant association (P<10-4) and describes a dose-response relationship, without confirmation that effect estimates with CIs are reported in the full text, the decision remains uncertain.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) includes PM2.5 as exposure, (3) outcome is asthma hospitalization which is a respiratory hospitalization, (4) uses case-crossover study design (time-stratified), (5) reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% CIs (0.31% increase per 1-μg/m3 PM2.5, 95% CI 0.24-0.37%), and (6) published in English. Asthma hospitalizations are a subset of respiratory hospitalizations and clearly relevant to the review objectives.

This is an original case-crossover study examining the association between air pollution (with PM2.5 as the primary pollutant) and respiratory hospitalizations/ED visits for childhood asthma. The study reports odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals. Although the primary exposure is the Air Quality Index, the authors explicitly state that PM2.5 was the primary pollutant responsible for the AQI (62% of days) and that the association was strongest for PM2.5-specific AQI. The outcome includes both ED visits and hospitalizations for asthma, which are respiratory outcomes. All inclusion criteria are met.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using a time-stratified case-crossover design; (2) exposure is PM2.5; (3) outcomes include respiratory hospitalizations (32 respiratory discharge diagnoses); (4) the study design is case-crossover; (5) the abstract indicates associations were estimated with PM2.5 (effect estimates are reported for respiratory outcomes showing positive associations for 31 of 32 outcomes); (6) published in English. Although the study also examines cardiovascular outcomes, it explicitly includes respiratory hospitalizations as a primary outcome of interest.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using time-series analysis with DLNM, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as one of the exposures, (3) the outcome is hospital admissions for respiratory diseases, (4) the study design is time-series, (5) it reports relative risks with 95% confidence intervals for PM2.5 (RR: 1.030, 95% CI: 1.012-1.049), and (6) the article appears to be published in English. Although multiple air pollutants are examined, PM2.5 is specifically included and analyzed.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using case-crossover design, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly included as an exposure along with NO2 and PM10, (3) outcome is respiratory emergency department presentations and hospitalizations for bronchiolitis, (4) uses time-stratified case-crossover design, (5) reports odds ratios with quantitative effect estimates (>10% increased risk for PM2.5), and (6) published in English. The study specifically states PM2.5 exposure increased PED presentation risk by more than 10%.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using distributional lagged nonlinear models, (2) PM2.5 is one of the exposures analyzed, (3) the outcome is respiratory hospitalization (acute upper respiratory infections), (4) it uses a time series design as stated in the title and methods, (5) it reports relative risk with 95% confidence intervals (RR=1.0247, 95% CI: 1.0092, 1.0405 for PM2.5), and (6) the abstract is in English. Although it also examines other pollutants (PM10, SO2, NO2), PM2.5 results are clearly reported.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcomes include respiratory hospitalizations and emergency department visits, (4) study design is case-crossover as explicitly stated, (5) reports odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals, and (6) published in English. Although the population studied is specific (childhood cancer survivors), this does not violate any exclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a case-crossover design, examines PM2.5 exposure (among other pollutants), reports respiratory hospitalizations (bronchiolitis) as the outcome, and provides odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals for PM2.5 (OR=1.04 [1.02-1.06]).

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) It is an original epidemiological study using a case-crossover design, (2) PM2.5/fine particulate matter is the primary exposure of interest, (3) respiratory hospitalizations in children is the outcome, (4) case-crossover design is specified, (5) odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals are reported (e.g., OR=1.004 [0.955-1.056] and OR=1.084 [1.007-1.167]), and (6) the abstract is in English. Although the study also examines oxidant gases and particle constituents as effect modifiers, PM2.5 remains a primary exposure with quantitative estimates provided.

While this is a time-series study that examines PM2.5 exposure and reports effect estimates (RR = 1.0216), the outcome is hospitalization specifically for SARS-CoV-2/COVID-19, not general respiratory hospitalizations. The study focuses on how air pollution exposure affects COVID-19 hospitalization risk rather than respiratory hospitalizations broadly. This is a specific infectious disease outcome that falls outside the typical scope of respiratory hospitalization studies examining air pollution effects on general respiratory conditions (asthma, COPD, pneumonia, etc.).

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly examined as an exposure, (3) the outcome is respiratory ED visits for asthma, (4) it uses a time-series study design (quasi-Poisson log-linear time-series models), (5) it reports rate ratios with 95% credible intervals (e.g., RR=1.016, 95% CI: 1.008-1.025 for PM2.5), and (6) it is published in English in a peer-reviewed journal.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using case-crossover design, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcomes include both respiratory ED presentations and hospital admissions, (4) case-crossover study design explicitly stated, (5) reports incidence rate ratios with 95% CIs (IRR=1.043, 95% CI: 1.000-1.089 for ED; IRR=1.013, 95% CI: 0.971-1.056 for admissions), and (6) published in English.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as one of the exposures, (3) the outcome is respiratory hospitalizations, (4) it uses a time-series design with GAMs and DLNMs, (5) it reports quantitative effect estimates including relative risk and percentage increases in hospitalization risk, and (6) it is published in English. Although PM2.5 is analyzed alongside other pollutants, this is acceptable per the inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) examines PM2.5 exposure (along with PM10), (3) outcome is respiratory disease hospitalizations, (4) uses time-series analysis with GAM, (5) reports risk estimates for hospitalizations (mentions 'increased risks'), and (6) published in English. Although the abstract does not explicitly show the effect estimates with confidence intervals, it clearly states that PM2.5 was 'associated with increased risks of hospitalizations for RD' and conducted quantitative analysis using time-series methods.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a case-crossover design, examines PM2.5 exposure (specifically wildfire smoke PM2.5), reports respiratory hospitalizations as an outcome (among other cardiorespiratory outcomes including acute respiratory infections, pneumonia, COPD, asthma, and other respiratory diseases), and provides relative risk estimates with 95% confidence intervals. While the study also examines cardiovascular outcomes, it includes relevant respiratory hospitalization outcomes which satisfy the inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using generalized additive Poisson model, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome includes respiratory hospitalizations (hospital admissions for URTI), (4) time-series design (daily PM2.5 concentrations analyzed with short-term lags), (5) reports quantitative effect estimate with 95% CI (0.84% increase per 10 μg/m³, 95% CI 0.05-1.64%), and (6) published in English. URTI are respiratory conditions and hospital admissions are a relevant outcome for this review.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using time-series analysis, (2) PM2.5 is analyzed as one of multiple exposures, (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalizations (asthma and COPD), (4) time-series design explicitly stated, (5) reports risk ratios with 95% CIs for PM2.5 exposure (asthma: 0.981-1.148; COPD: 0.966-1.019), and (6) published in English. Although PM2.5 associations were not statistically significant, the study provides quantitative estimates relevant to the systematic review.

While this study meets criteria for exposure (PM2.5), outcome (respiratory hospitalization), and reports effect estimates with confidence intervals, it does not meet the study design criterion. The abstract explicitly describes this as a 'retrospective cohort study' rather than a time-series or case-crossover design. Although distributed lag models are used (which are common in time-series analyses), the fundamental design is cohort-based with person-months of follow-up rather than a time-series or case-crossover approach.

While this is an original epidemiological study with a time-series design that includes PM2.5 exposure and reports effect estimates with confidence intervals, the primary outcomes are cardiovascular and cerebrovascular ED visits, not respiratory hospitalizations/ED visits. Although respiratory conditions are mentioned and show increased risk (RR 1.18), they appear to be a secondary outcome used for comparison, not the main focus of the study.

This is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory ED visits (pneumonia, COPD/asthma). The study uses a time-series design with distributed lag models and quasi-Poisson regression using daily data. It reports RR/OR with 95% CIs for respiratory outcomes including pneumonia ED visits (RR = 1.071, 95% CI: 1.025-1.118). Although the study also examines cardiovascular outcomes and other pollutants, it meets all inclusion criteria for the respiratory component with PM2.5 exposure.

While this study examines PM2.5 exposure and respiratory (pneumonia) hospitalizations with quantitative effect estimates, the study design is a prospective cohort study rather than the required time-series or case-crossover design. The inclusion criteria specifically limit eligible studies to time-series or case-crossover designs only.

This is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory emergency room visits. It uses a generalized additive model (indicating time-series design) to analyze short-term effects with lagged exposures. The study reports relative risks with 95% confidence intervals for various respiratory outcomes including total respiratory ERVs, asthma, bronchitis, and COPD. All inclusion criteria are met.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) It is an original epidemiological study, not a review or commentary; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly included as one of the exposures analyzed; (3) The outcome is respiratory hospital admissions; (4) The study design is case-crossover, which is specified in the inclusion criteria; (5) Quantitative effect estimates are reported as percentage change in odds with 95% CI (1.2% increase per 10 μg/m3 PM2.5 at lag 0-2); (6) The article appears to be published in English based on the abstract provided.

While this is an original time-series study with PM2.5 exposure and quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals, the outcome is hospitalization for rheumatoid arthritis-associated interstitial lung disease (RA-ILD), which is a specific autoimmune/rheumatologic condition with secondary lung involvement, not a primary respiratory hospitalization. The systematic review targets respiratory hospitalizations, which typically include conditions like asthma, COPD, pneumonia, and other primary respiratory diseases, not autoimmune diseases with pulmonary manifestations.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome is respiratory emergency department visits (asthma/wheeze, bronchitis, pneumonia, upper respiratory infections), (4) study design is case-crossover (time-stratified), (5) reports odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals, and (6) published in English in Environmental Health Perspectives.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 exposure explicitly stated, (3) respiratory hospitalizations and ED visits for asthma and COPD as outcomes, (4) time-stratified case-crossover design, (5) reports excess rates with 95% CI (e.g., ER = 2.1%, 95% CI = 0.7%, 3.6%), and (6) appears to be in English. No exclusion criteria apply.

The title mentions 'hospitalization' but the abstract clearly describes the outcome as 'outpatient visits' for upper respiratory tract infections, not hospitalizations or emergency department visits. The study uses a generalized additive model (time-series design) and examines PM2.5 exposure, which meet inclusion criteria, but the outcome does not match the required respiratory hospitalization/ED visit criterion.

This is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory outcomes including both ED visits and hospitalizations. The study uses Poisson regression with daily county-level counts, which is consistent with time-series methodology. The study reports multiple quantitative effect estimates (RR) with 95% confidence intervals for respiratory disease outcomes, including overall respiratory disease, asthma, and CLRD. The study meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 (along with other pollutants) as an exposure and AECOPD hospitalizations as the outcome. It reports quantitative effect estimates (RR with 95% CI). AECOPD hospitalization is a respiratory hospitalization outcome. Although the study focuses on interaction effects with temperature, it still provides PM2.5-specific results and meets all inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a time-series design to examine the association between PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospital admissions in Kuwait. The study reports a clear quantitative effect estimate (1.61% increase per 10 μg/m3 increase in PM2.5) with 95% confidence intervals (0.87, 2.35%). The exposure is PM2.5, the outcome is respiratory hospitalizations, and the study appears to be published in English.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a case-crossover design, examines PM2.5 exposure (source-specific PM2.5), reports respiratory hospitalizations and ED visits as outcomes (influenza and pneumonia are respiratory conditions), and provides quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals (excess rates with 95% CIs). The study analyzes PM2.5 among other exposures, which is acceptable per inclusion criteria.

This is an original time-series study using generalized additive models examining PM2.5 (among other pollutants) exposure and emergency department visits for upper respiratory tract infection. It reports quantitative effect estimates (percentage increase) with 95% confidence intervals for PM2.5. URTI is a respiratory condition requiring ED visits, which meets the respiratory hospitalization/ED visit outcome criterion.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using a generalized additive model; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as one of the exposures; (3) the outcome is respiratory hospitalization (pneumonia and asthma) in children; (4) the study design is time-series based on the methodology described (GAM with lag structures, analyzing daily hospitalization rates against air pollutant concentrations); (5) quantitative effect estimates with 95% CIs are reported (2.22% increase per 10-unit PM2.5 increase, 95%CI: 0.64%, 3.82%); and (6) the article is in English. Although multiple pollutants are analyzed, PM2.5 is specifically included and reported separately.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using time-series analysis, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome is asthma emergency room admissions which qualifies as respiratory ED visits, (4) time-series study design, (5) reports quantitative effect estimate of 7.2% increase with 95% CI (1.7-13.1%), and (6) published in English. Asthma admissions/ED visits are a well-established respiratory hospitalization outcome.

This is an original case-crossover study examining PM2.5 (among other pollutants) and respiratory hospitalizations for interstitial lung diseases. ILDs are respiratory conditions requiring hospitalization. The study reports quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals. PM2.5 is explicitly mentioned as one of the exposures assessed, even though the abstract primarily reports results for SO2 and NO2. The study meets all inclusion criteria.

While this is a time-series study analyzing PM2.5 (among other pollutants) and respiratory hospitalizations with effect estimates, the abstract does not report the specific RR or OR for PM2.5 and respiratory outcomes. The results section only presents effect estimates for NO2, ozone, and noise, but not for PM2.5, despite it being listed as an exposure variable in the methods. Without the PM2.5-respiratory hospitalization effect estimate being reported in the abstract, we cannot confirm this study meets criterion 5 for inclusion.

This is an original epidemiological study using time-series methodology (GAM with distributed lag models) examining PM2.5 exposure and COPD hospitalizations. The study reports quantitative effect estimates (percentage increases in daily admissions). COPD hospitalizations are a respiratory hospitalization outcome. Although the effect estimates are reported as percentage changes rather than RR/OR format, they are quantitative measures that can be converted.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Original epidemiological study; (2) Exposure includes PM2.5; (3) Outcome is respiratory hospitalizations; (4) Case-crossover design; (5) Reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% CIs (1.73% increase, 95% CI: 1.34%, 2.12% for PM2.5); (6) Published in English. Although the study also examines PM2.5-10 (coarse particles), PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed and reported.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original ecological time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospitalizations (pneumonia, bronchitis, bronchiolitis, asthma). The study reports relative risk estimates with values (RR = 1.017, 1.022, 1.020 at different lags) for a 5 µg/m3 increase in PM2.5. The study uses appropriate time-series methodology with generalized additive Poisson regression and controls for confounders. Published in English with Portuguese translation.

This study meets most inclusion criteria: it examines PM2.5 exposure, respiratory hospitalizations in children, reports RR with 95% CI, and appears to be an original epidemiological study. However, the study design is described as 'difference-in-differences approach generalized to multiple spatial units and time periods with distributed lag non-linear models' rather than explicitly as time-series or case-crossover. While it uses daily data and distributed lag models (common in time-series), the difference-in-differences framework is methodologically distinct from traditional time-series or case-crossover designs, creating uncertainty about whether it strictly meets the design inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly included as one of the exposures analyzed, (3) the outcome is emergency department visits for respiratory diseases (COPD and upper respiratory diseases), (4) uses a case-crossover study design, (5) reports positive associations with specific lag periods indicating quantitative effect estimates were calculated, and (6) the abstract is in English. While the abstract does not explicitly state RR/OR values, it clearly indicates that associations were tested and positive results were found, which implies effect estimates with statistical significance were reported in the full paper.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using time-series design, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalization (ALRI including CAP, AECB, AECOPD, AEB), (4) time-series study design explicitly stated, (5) reports percent increases with 95% confidence intervals that can be converted to relative risks, and (6) published in English. All quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals are provided.

This is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure and hospital admissions across multiple disease categories including respiratory diseases. The study reports quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals. Although the study examines multiple outcomes beyond just respiratory hospitalizations, respiratory disease hospitalizations are explicitly included as one of the major disease categories analyzed. The study meets all inclusion criteria: original epidemiological study, PM2.5 exposure, includes respiratory hospitalization outcome, time-series design, reports effect measures with CIs, and is published in English.

This is an original time-series study using generalized additive model with Poisson regression to examine PM2.5 exposure and asthma emergency room visits. The study reports relative risks with 95% confidence intervals for both PM2.5 and PM2.5-bound PAH components. Asthma exacerbations requiring emergency room visits are respiratory outcomes relevant to the review. PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as one of the exposures with quantitative effect estimates provided.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) examines PM2.5 exposure (along with PM10), (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalization, (4) uses time-series design explicitly stated in title and abstract, (5) reports percentage change with 95% CI (PM2.5: 0.755%; 95% CI: 0.422, 1.089%), and (6) published in English. The study analyzes both PM2.5 and PM10, which is acceptable per inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) includes PM2.5 as exposure, (3) outcome is asthma-related emergency department visits (AEDv) which is a respiratory ED visit, (4) uses time-series design, (5) reports relative risks with specific quantitative estimates (4.4% increase per IQR of PM2.5), and (6) published in English. Although multiple pollutants were analyzed, PM2.5 is clearly one of them with specific effect estimates provided.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 is one of multiple exposures analyzed, (3) outcome is asthma-related hospital admissions and emergency department visits (respiratory hospitalizations), (4) case-crossover design explicitly stated, (5) reports associations with 95% confidence intervals mentioned in results, and (6) published in English. Although it examines multiple pollutants, PM2.5 is specifically analyzed and reported.

This is an original epidemiological study that examines PM2.5 exposure (along with PM10) and includes respiratory hospitalizations as one of the outcomes. It uses a time-series design (GAM on daily data 2015-2016) and reports quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals (1.03% increase per 10 μg/m3 PM2.5, 95% CI: 0.50%-1.56% for respiratory HAs). Although the study examines multiple outcomes beyond respiratory hospitalizations, it meets all inclusion criteria including PM2.5 exposure, respiratory hospitalization outcome, time-series design, and quantitative effect estimates.

This is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 (among other particle metrics) in relation to hospital admissions including respiratory outcomes. While the abstract emphasizes cardiovascular results, it explicitly states that secondary pollutants including PM2.5 were important for respiratory outcomes and mentions emergency hospital admissions were collected. The study uses Poisson regression time-series analysis and reports effect estimates with confidence intervals. It meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an original epidemiological study using time-series design (GAMs on daily hospital admissions) that examines PM2.5 exposure among multiple pollutants. While it examines multiple organ systems, it explicitly reports effects on respiratory system hospitalizations (1.36% for NO2, and PM2.5 effects are analyzed for respiratory outcomes as part of 'most disease categories'). The study reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals and is published in English.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a time-series design, examines PM2.5 exposure (along with PM10), reports respiratory hospitalizations and ED visits for asthma exacerbations as outcomes, and provides relative risk estimates with confidence intervals. The study explicitly states RR values for PM2.5 (e.g., RR=1.24 for ED admissions, RR=1.31 for hospitalizations).

While this is a time-series study examining respiratory ED visits with effect estimates, the primary exposure of interest is climate parameters (precipitation and temperature) on thunderstorm days, not PM2.5. Although PM2.5 was included as a covariate in the model, the study explicitly states that 'Daily maximum O3 and PM2.5 levels were not significantly associated with asthma ED visits on thunderstorm days,' and no effect estimates for PM2.5 are provided. The study does not meet the primary criterion of examining PM2.5 as the main exposure of interest.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as one of the exposures, (3) the outcome is respiratory hospitalizations (acute lower respiratory tract infections including pneumonia and bronchitis), (4) it uses a time-series design with generalized additive model, (5) it reports relative risks with 95% confidence intervals for PM2.5 (RR=1.0064, 95% CI 1.0004-1.0124 for pneumonia and RR=1.0133, 95% CI 1.0025-1.0242 for bronchitis), and (6) the abstract is in English. The study analyzes multiple pollutants but PM2.5 is one of them with specific effect estimates reported.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a case-crossover design, examines PM2.5 exposure (along with PM10), reports respiratory hospitalizations for asthma and COPD as outcomes, provides odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals, and appears to be published in English.

This is an original epidemiological study that examines PM2.5 exposure (along with ultrafine particles) and respiratory hospital admissions. The study uses a time-series design with daily counts of hospital admissions analyzed using Poisson regression models. It reports quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals for PM2.5 and respiratory admissions (7.5% increase, 95% CI: 4.9-10.2% per 12.4 μg/m3 increase). All inclusion criteria are met.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using time-series analysis to examine the association between PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospital admissions. It reports quantitative effect estimates (percent increases in hospitalization rates per 10 μg/m3 increase in PM2.5) for different racial/ethnic groups. The study design, exposure, outcome, and reporting of effect measures all align with the inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a time-stratified case-crossover design, examines PM2.5 exposure, reports respiratory hospitalizations as an outcome, provides quantitative effect estimates with 95% CIs (1.74% increase per 10-μg/m3 PM2.5 for respiratory admissions, 95% CI: 1.41-2.07%), and appears to be published in English.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) examines PM2.5 exposure, (3) reports respiratory hospitalizations as an outcome, (4) uses a case-crossover design, (5) provides quantitative effect estimates with 95% CI (1.95% increase, 95% CI 1.63-2.27% for respiratory diseases per 10 μg/m3 increase in PM2.5), and (6) is published in English. The study examines both cardiovascular and respiratory outcomes, but respiratory hospitalization is clearly reported as a separate outcome.

While this is a time-series study examining respiratory hospitalizations with effect estimates, the primary exposure is particle oxidative potential (OP), not PM2.5 mass concentration. PM2.5 was measured only as a carrier for the OP metrics (OP(AA) and OP(GSH)), which were the actual exposures analyzed. The study does not report associations between PM2.5 mass concentration and respiratory hospitalizations.

This is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 (fine particulate matter) exposure and emergency department visits for pediatric asthma. The study uses a time-series design with daily data and Poisson generalized linear models. It reports rate ratios with 95% confidence intervals for source-specific PM2.5 associations. All inclusion criteria are met.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Original epidemiological study using GAM for time-series analysis; (2) PM2.5 exposure explicitly analyzed; (3) Respiratory disease hospitalization as outcome; (4) Time-series design with short-term effect assessment; (5) Reports percentage increase in risk with 95% confidence intervals (convertible to relative risk); (6) Published in English. The study provides quantitative effect estimates for PM2.5 and respiratory hospitalizations.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using time-series design, (2) exposure is PM2.5 from landscape fires, (3) outcome includes respiratory hospitalizations (specifically asthma and other respiratory diseases mentioned), (4) time-series study design explicitly stated, (5) reports risk ratios with 95% confidence intervals (e.g., RR 1.16, 95% CI 1.00 to 1.35 for asthma), and (6) published in English. While the study also examines cardiovascular outcomes, it clearly includes respiratory hospitalizations as a primary outcome.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using time-series analysis, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as one of the exposures, (3) the outcome is chronic respiratory disease (CRD) hospitalizations, (4) the study design is time-series, (5) quantitative effect estimates with 95% CIs are reported (2.13% increase, 95% CI: 0.55%, 3.74% for PM2.5), and (6) the abstract is in English. The study analyzes multiple pollutants but PM2.5 is specifically examined and reported.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) exposure is PM2.5/fine particulate matter, (3) outcome is respiratory healthcare visits (which includes hospitalizations and/or ED visits), (4) case-crossover design with time-stratified approach, (5) reports odds ratios with effect estimates for PM2.5 increases, and (6) published in English. The study examines pediatric respiratory outcomes including asthma, LRTI, and URTI in relation to short-term PM2.5 exposure.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as one of multiple exposures, (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalization in children, (4) uses time-stratified case-crossover design, (5) reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% CI (OR=1.017, 95%CI: 1.003-1.031 for PM2.5), and (6) published in English. The study examines multiple pollutants but PM2.5 results are clearly reported.

This is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure (among other exposures) and respiratory outcomes including ED and inpatient visits for asthma exacerbation. While the primary focus is on effect modification by viral infections and most results are for aeroallergens, the study explicitly includes PM2.5 as an exposure and examines ED visits and hospitalizations (inpatient visits) as outcomes. Rate ratios with confidence intervals are reported, though specific PM2.5 results are not detailed in the abstract. Meets inclusion criteria despite PM2.5 being one of multiple exposures analyzed.

This study meets the inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using time-series analysis (GAM with daily data) to examine PM2.5 exposure (among other pollutants) and respiratory hospitalizations (patients with respiratory diseases and comorbid diabetes). The study reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% CIs (7.25% increase per 10 μg/m3 PM2.5). Although the population is restricted to those with diabetes comorbidity, the outcome is still respiratory hospitalization, which meets the inclusion criteria.

While this study meets most inclusion criteria (original epidemiological study, time-series design, PM2.5 exposure, quantitative effect estimates with CI), it should be excluded because the outcome is acute upper respiratory tract infections (AURTIs), which are typically minor infections (common cold, pharyngitis) rather than the lower respiratory conditions (pneumonia, COPD, asthma) that constitute the primary focus of respiratory hospitalization studies. AURTIs generally represent less severe respiratory conditions and may not align with the clinical severity implied by 'respiratory hospitalizations' in the review scope.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using generalized additive models, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly studied as an exposure, (3) the outcome is emergency department visits for asthma (a respiratory condition), (4) it uses a time-series study design as stated in the title, (5) it reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals (e.g., 6.1% increase, 95% CI: 2.1-10.3%), and (6) it is published in English. The study examines respiratory-related emergency visits, which aligns with the systematic review's focus on respiratory hospitalizations/ED visits.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome includes respiratory hospitalizations, (4) uses case time series design (a variant of time-series), (5) reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% CI (1.43% increase with 95% CI: 1.34%, 1.52% for respiratory hospitalizations per 10 μg/m³ PM2.5 increment), and (6) appears to be published in English. Although the study also examines cardiovascular outcomes, it includes respiratory hospitalizations as a separate outcome of interest.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 and COPD hospitalizations, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalization (COPD admissions), (4) case-crossover study design, (5) reports quantitative effect estimate with 95% CI (1.6% increase, 95% CI: 0.6%, 2.7% per 10 μg/m3), and (6) published in English. COPD is a respiratory condition and hospitalizations for COPD qualify as respiratory hospitalizations.

While this study meets several inclusion criteria (original epidemiological study, case-crossover design, reports OR with CI, includes PM2.5 as one exposure), it should be excluded because the outcome is 'pediatric asthma visit treated with prednisone' rather than specifically hospitalization or ED visit. The abstract does not clearly specify whether these visits were hospitalizations or ED visits. Additionally, the primary exposure of interest is ultrafine particles, not PM2.5, and the results explicitly state 'We observed no such associations with...fine particles (≤2.5μm)', indicating no significant PM2.5 effect.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using case-crossover design, (2) includes PM2.5 as one of multiple exposures analyzed, (3) outcome is respiratory hospital admissions, (4) case-crossover design explicitly stated, (5) reports associations/effect estimates for PM2.5 with respiratory admissions in both single and multi-pollutant models, and (6) published in English. The abstract clearly states quantitative relationships were computed between PM2.5 and respiratory admissions.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalization (COPD), (4) case-crossover design, (5) reports odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals, and (6) published in English. COPD hospitalization is a respiratory hospitalization outcome.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) examines PM2.5 exposure, (3) includes respiratory hospitalizations as an outcome with specific effect estimates reported (0.26% increase, 95% CI = 0.22%, 0.31% for respiratory admissions per 10 μg/m³ PM2.5), (4) uses case-crossover design as stated in title and confirmed by use of conditional logistic regression, (5) reports effect estimates with confidence intervals, and (6) published in English.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a time-series design (Quasi-Poisson regression with distributed lag model) examining the association between PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospitalizations (asthma, COPD, bronchiectasis). The study reports relative risks with 95% confidence intervals for PM2.5 and respiratory hospital admissions. Although multiple air pollutants were studied, PM2.5 is explicitly included and analyzed with quantitative effect estimates provided.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a case-crossover design, examines PM2.5 exposure, reports respiratory hospitalizations (pneumonia) as the outcome, and provides quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals.

The primary exposure is coarse particles (PM2.5-10), not PM2.5. While the abstract mentions PM2.5 as an adjustment variable and contextualizes the research, the study's main focus is evaluating the relationship between coarse particles and respiratory ED visits. This does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring PM2.5 as the exposure of interest.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Original epidemiological study using GAM for time-series analysis, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly studied as one of multiple air pollutants, (3) Outcome is hospital admissions for asthma, which is a respiratory hospitalization, (4) Time-series study design clearly stated in title and methods, (5) Reports relative risk values with 95% confidence intervals for PM2.5 (RR=1.015, 95% CI: 1.003-1.028 per 10 μg/m3 increase), and (6) Published in English. Although the outcome is specifically asthma rather than all respiratory conditions, asthma hospitalizations are a subset of respiratory hospitalizations and highly relevant to PM2.5 exposure research.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly studied as one of the exposures, (3) the outcomes are respiratory ED admissions and hospitalizations for COPD exacerbation, (4) it uses a time-series design with Poisson regression, (5) it reports relative risks with statistical significance for PM2.5 exposure, and (6) the abstract is in English. COPD exacerbation is a respiratory condition requiring hospitalization/ED visit.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a time-series design, examines PM2.5 exposure (among other pollutants), measures respiratory emergency department visits as the outcome, and reports rate ratios with 95% credible intervals. The study also examines ozone, but PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed and reported separately.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study; (2) exposure is PM2.5 from various sources; (3) outcome includes respiratory emergency department visits; (4) uses case-crossover study design; (5) reports excess risk with 95% confidence intervals for respiratory outcomes; and (6) published in English. While the study also examines cardiovascular outcomes, it includes respiratory ED visits which meets the outcome criterion.

This is an original time-series epidemiological study examining the association between PM2.5 (among other air pollutants) and asthma hospitalizations. The study uses generalized additive models to analyze daily asthma hospitalizations, which is a respiratory outcome. The abstract indicates that effect estimates (attributable risks) were calculated, and the results mention that PM2.5 was associated with the heaviest burden in heating season. Although PM2.5 is studied alongside other pollutants (SO2, NO2, PM10, O3), this meets the inclusion criteria as PM2.5 is one of multiple exposures analyzed. The study design is time-series, the outcome is respiratory hospitalization, and quantitative effect measures are reported.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as one of the exposures, (3) the outcome is respiratory hospital admissions, (4) the study design is time-series using quasi-Poisson regression with DLNM, (5) it reports relative risks with 95% confidence intervals (RR 1.089, 95% CI 1.001-1.183 for PM2.5), and (6) it is published in English. While the study examines multiple pollutants, PM2.5 is clearly analyzed and reported with quantitative effect estimates.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) It is an original epidemiological study using a generalized additive model; (2) PM2.5 is one of the exposures examined; (3) The outcome is hospital admissions for acute bronchitis, which is a respiratory hospitalization; (4) It explicitly uses a time-series study design; (5) It reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals (1.23% increase, 95% CI 0.21-2.26% per 10 µg/m3 PM2.5 increase); (6) The article appears to be published in English based on the abstract provided.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using time-series design, includes PM2.5 as one of the exposures analyzed, examines respiratory ED visits (asthma) as the outcome, reports rate ratios (RRs) with confidence intervals, and appears to be published in English. Although multiple pollutants were studied, PM2.5 is explicitly included in the analysis.

While this study includes PM2.5 (fine particulate matter) as one exposure and respiratory hospitalizations as the outcome, the abstract only reports effect estimates for temperature, not for PM2.5. The results section focuses exclusively on temperature effects (18% increase in risk per 4°C increase in minimum temperature) without providing any quantitative effect estimate for PM2.5. The study design appears to be time-series with Poisson regression models, which meets criteria, but without reported PM2.5 effect estimates with confidence intervals, it does not meet inclusion criterion #5 for the purposes of a systematic review on PM2.5 and respiratory hospitalizations.

This is an original time-series study examining the association between PM2.5 (and ozone) and cardiorespiratory outcomes including respiratory hospitalizations and ED visits. The study reports quantitative effect estimates (risk ratios) with specific values mentioned for respiratory disease outcomes. Although the primary focus is on comparing different visit types, it meets all inclusion criteria: original epidemiological study, PM2.5 exposure assessed, respiratory hospitalizations/ED visits as outcomes, time-series design, and reports risk ratios for respiratory outcomes.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Original epidemiological study using a case time series design; (2) Exposure is PM2.5; (3) Outcomes include both respiratory hospitalizations and ED visits; (4) Case time series is an acceptable study design similar to time-series; (5) Reports excess relative risks with 95% confidence intervals for respiratory hospitalizations (ERR not specified numerically but stated as 'statistically significantly associated') and respiratory ED visits (ERR 1.34%, 95% CI 0.73% to 1.94%); (6) Published in English. Although the study also examines cardiovascular and natural cause outcomes, it explicitly includes respiratory hospitalizations and ED visits as outcomes of interest.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 is analyzed as one of multiple exposures, (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalization for COPD exacerbations, (4) case-crossover design clearly stated, (5) reports rate ratios with 95% CIs for PM2.5 (RR=1.030, 95% CI: 1.006-1.055), and (6) published in English. COPD exacerbations requiring hospitalization are a respiratory hospitalization outcome.

This is an original time-series epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospitalizations (among other outcomes). It explicitly states that respiratory hospital admissions were analyzed using generalized linear models with distributed-lag approaches. The study reports significant associations (effect estimates) between source-specific PM2.5 and respiratory admissions. All inclusion criteria are met: original epidemiological study, PM2.5 exposure, respiratory hospitalization outcome, time-series design, and quantitative effect estimates are reported.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) It is an original epidemiological study using generalized additive models with distributed lag models, indicating a time-series design. (2) PM2.5 is explicitly included as one of the exposures analyzed. (3) The outcome is emergency department visits for pediatric asthma, which is a respiratory ED visit. (4) The study design is time-series (generalized additive model with daily ED visits). (5) Quantitative effect estimates are reported as relative risks with 95% confidence intervals (e.g., RR=1.011, 95%CI: 1.002, 1.021 for PM2.5). (6) The article appears to be published in English. While the study examines multiple pollutants, PM2.5 is specifically analyzed and reported, making it appropriate for inclusion.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using time-series analysis with case-crossover design as indicated in title; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly studied as one of multiple exposures; (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalization (asthma admissions); (4) uses time-series methodology; (5) reports rate ratios with 95% CI for PM2.5 (RR=1.014, 95%CI: 1.000-1.028 per 10 µg/m3); (6) published in English. Despite the title mentioning 'case-crossover', the abstract describes it as 'time-series analysis', which satisfies the design requirement.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using time-series regression analysis, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly examined as an exposure, (3) outcome is hospitalization for acute lower respiratory infections (ALRI) including pneumonia and bronchiolitis, (4) time-series study design, (5) reports relative risk with 95% confidence intervals for PM2.5 (RR=1.089, 95%CI:1.075, 1.103 per 10 µg/m3 increase), and (6) published in English. The study examines multiple pollutants but PM2.5 is specifically analyzed with quantitative effect estimates.

This is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospitalizations (including asthma-related hospitalizations). It uses a time-series design with Poisson regression analyzing county-specific effects over lag periods. The study reports percentage increases with 95% confidence intervals, which are equivalent to relative risk measures. Although the study also examines cardiovascular outcomes, it includes respiratory hospitalizations as a primary outcome and meets all inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using generalized linear Poisson regression models; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly measured as one of the exposures; (3) the outcome is respiratory emergency room admissions; (4) the study design is time-series (daily counts with lag analysis); (5) quantitative effect estimates with 95% CIs are reported for multiple pollutants; (6) published in English. Although the study found no significant association between PM2.5 and ER admissions, it still examined PM2.5 as an exposure and reported findings, making it eligible for inclusion in the systematic review.

While this is an interrupted time series study that uses PM2.5 exposure estimates and examines respiratory hospitalizations among other outcomes, it is focused on long-term effects (8 years post-event) rather than the typical short-term associations examined in time-series studies. The study design (interrupted time series examining a single event's long-term impact) differs from traditional time-series studies that examine day-to-day or week-to-week variations in PM2.5 and health outcomes. Additionally, the abstract does not clearly indicate whether quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals are reported specifically for the PM2.5-respiratory hospitalization association.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using time-series design with Poisson generalized linear models; (2) PM2.5 (including organic carbon fraction) is explicitly examined as an exposure; (3) the outcome is respiratory ED visits for infections (bronchitis, bronchiolitis, pneumonia, URI); (4) it is a time-series study; (5) quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals are reported (e.g., 4% increase with 95% CI: 2%, 6% for URI; 8% increase with 95% CI: 4%, 13% for pneumonia); and (6) it is published in English. While PM2.5 is analyzed alongside other pollutants (ozone, nitrogen dioxide), it is specifically included as one of the exposures of interest.

The study examines PM10 (not PM2.5) exposure and the outcomes are pulmonary embolism and venous thrombosis hospitalizations, which are cardiovascular/thrombotic conditions, not respiratory conditions. The study does not meet the exposure requirement (PM2.5) or the outcome requirement (respiratory hospitalizations).
The outcome is suicide death, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visit. The exposure is PM10, not PM2.5. Both the exposure and outcome fail to meet the inclusion criteria.

This is a critical review/meta-analysis of PM10-mortality studies, not an original epidemiological study. Additionally, the exposure is PM10 (not PM2.5), and the outcome is mortality (not respiratory hospitalization or ED visit). Fails multiple inclusion criteria.

This is a systematic review/meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. Additionally, the outcome is coronary/cardiovascular disease, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. The exposure also does not specifically mention PM2.5.

This is a meta-analysis/systematic review (not an original epidemiological study) examining mortality (not hospitalization/ED visits) as the outcome. The exposure is PM10, not PM2.5. It fails multiple inclusion criteria.

The study examines out-of-hospital cardiac arrests (OHCAs) of cardiac origin as the outcome, not respiratory hospitalizations or emergency department visits. While the study meets other criteria (PM2.5 exposure, case-crossover design, reports effect estimates with CI), the outcome does not match the inclusion criteria for this systematic review focused on respiratory hospitalizations.

This is an animal study (mice) investigating the biological mechanism of PM2.5-induced lung injury and pharmaceutical intervention, not an epidemiological study examining respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits in humans. The study design is experimental laboratory research, not time-series or case-crossover. The outcome measured is lung injury biomarkers and inflammatory markers, not respiratory hospitalizations or emergency department visits.

This is explicitly stated to be a review article ('this review is focused on these aspects'), not an original epidemiological study. It discusses various aspects of particulate matter and lung diseases but does not present original data or quantitative effect estimates for the association between PM2.5 and respiratory hospitalizations.

The study examines PM10 (particulate matter ≤10 μm) exposure, not PM2.5 (particulate matter ≤2.5 μm). While the outcome (respiratory hospitalizations for COPD and asthma) and study design (time-series) meet inclusion criteria, the exposure measure does not match the required PM2.5 exposure specified in the inclusion criteria.

While this study includes a multisite time-series analysis of PM2.5 constituents and hospital admissions, the abstract specifically states the primary finding was for cardiovascular hospital admissions, not respiratory hospitalizations. The outcome does not match the inclusion criteria requiring respiratory hospitalization or ED visits.

The study focuses on PM10 (particulate matter ≤10 μm) rather than PM2.5 (≤2.5 μm), which does not meet the exposure inclusion criteria. While the study examines hospital admissions and uses an appropriate time-series design with quantitative effect estimates, the exposure measure is explicitly PM10, not PM2.5.

While this is an original case-crossover study examining respiratory hospitalizations with quantitative effect estimates, the exposure is PM10 (particles ≤10 µm) rather than PM2.5 (particles ≤2.5 µm). The abstract explicitly states PM10 and does not mention PM2.5 as an exposure variable.

While this is an original time-series study examining respiratory hospitalizations with reported effect estimates, the exposure measure is PM10 (particles ≤10 μm) rather than PM2.5 (particles ≤2.5 μm). The study explicitly states that PM10 was used as the indicator of pollution throughout. PM2.5 is not mentioned anywhere in the abstract as being measured or analyzed.

This appears to be a health impact assessment or policy evaluation study rather than an original epidemiological study. The abstract states 'A literature review was carried out to determine the appropriate relative risk to be used in the estimations' and 'public health gains were calculated based on the selected relative risks for each city,' indicating the study used existing effect estimates from the literature rather than generating original estimates. It does not appear to report new relative risks or odds ratios from original data analysis, but rather applies published estimates to estimate avoidable hospitalizations under different air quality standards.

The study examines PM10 (particles <10 µm) rather than PM2.5 (particles ≤2.5 µm) as the exposure. Additionally, the outcome is emergency ambulance dispatches rather than respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits specifically. While respiratory diseases were mentioned, the effect estimate provided is for non-traumatic diseases overall, and the abstract states respiratory diseases did not reach statistical significance.

Although this is an original epidemiological study with a case-crossover design examining PM2.5 exposure and reporting effect estimates with confidence intervals, the outcome is ischemic stroke hospitalization, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. This does not meet the inclusion criteria for outcome.
The study examines PM10 (not PM2.5) as the exposure and cardiovascular events (not respiratory hospitalizations) as the outcome. Both the exposure and outcome fail to meet the inclusion criteria.

The study outcome is cardiovascular mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. While the study uses a time-series design (distributed lag model) and reports effect estimates, it does not meet the inclusion criteria for outcome. Additionally, the study mentions PM10 but does not specifically report PM2.5 as an exposure.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The abstract clearly states 'This systematic review was conducted' and mentions including '196 articles in quantitative analysis'. The outcome is mortality (all-cause, cardiovascular, respiratory, and cerebrovascular mortality), not respiratory hospitalizations or emergency department visits.

This is a review/book chapter that summarizes existing literature rather than an original epidemiological study. Additionally, the outcome is mortality rather than respiratory hospitalization or ED visit.

Although this is an original epidemiological study with a case-crossover design that examines PM2.5 exposure and reports effect estimates with confidence intervals, the outcome is myocardial infarction (MI) mortality, which is a cardiovascular outcome, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visit. This does not meet the inclusion criteria for a systematic review on respiratory hospitalizations.

Although this is an original case-crossover study that includes PM2.5 as an exposure and reports effect estimates with confidence intervals, the outcome is stroke hospitalization, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. The study does not meet inclusion criterion #3.

The exposure is PM10 (coarse particulate matter from mineral dust), not PM2.5. While the study design is case-crossover and examines respiratory outcomes, the outcome is respiratory symptoms (cough) rather than hospitalization or ED visits. The study does not meet the exposure criterion (PM2.5) or the outcome criterion (hospitalization/ED visit).

While this is an interrupted time-series study examining respiratory hospital visits with quantitative effect estimates, the exposure is PM10, not PM2.5. The study evaluates the impact of a burning ban on air pollution and respiratory hospitalizations, but PM10 is explicitly stated as the particulate matter measure used. PM2.5 is not mentioned in the abstract as being measured or analyzed.

The study examines ischemic stroke hospitalizations, not respiratory hospitalizations. The primary exposure is coarse particulate matter (PM10-2.5), not PM2.5, though PM2.5 is mentioned as a covariate. The outcome does not meet inclusion criteria.

While this is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure with quantitative effect estimates, the outcome is respiratory mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. The study examines cause-specific mortality including respiratory deaths, which does not meet the inclusion criteria requiring respiratory hospitalization/ED visits as the outcome.

This is a systematic literature review/meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria specifically require original epidemiological studies and exclude reviews and meta-analyses. While the review mentions that some included studies examined PM2.5 exposure, this publication itself is a secondary source synthesizing other studies.
Study examines PM10 (not PM2.5) exposure and respiratory mortality (not hospitalization/ED visits). Two critical inclusion criteria are not met: wrong exposure type and wrong outcome measure.
Study examines PM10 exposure (not PM2.5) and respiratory mortality (not hospitalization/ED visits). Both the exposure type and outcome do not meet inclusion criteria.

The study examines PM10 (particulate matter ≤10 µm), not PM2.5 (≤2.5 µm) as required by inclusion criteria. Additionally, the outcome is years of life lost (YLL) due to respiratory disease mortality, not respiratory hospitalizations or emergency department visits. While it is a time-series study with quantitative effect estimates, it fails to meet the key exposure and outcome criteria.

This is a meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria explicitly require original studies and exclude reviews and meta-analyses. Although it examines PM2.5 exposure and includes respiratory outcomes, it is a synthesis of 152 other studies rather than primary research.

The study examines PM10 (≤10µm) and NO2, not PM2.5 (≤2.5µm). While it includes respiratory hospitalizations as an outcome and uses appropriate study designs (time-series with Poisson regression and case-crossover for mortality), the exposure does not meet the inclusion criteria which specifically requires PM2.5 or fine particulate matter ≤2.5µm.

The study examines PM10 and O3 exposure, not PM2.5. The outcome is mortality, not hospitalization or emergency department visits. These violate the inclusion criteria requiring PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospitalization/ED visit outcomes.
This study examines PM10 (not PM2.5) as the exposure and mortality (not hospitalization or ED visits) as the outcome. Both the exposure and outcome fail to meet the inclusion criteria.

While this is a time-series study with quantitative effect estimates, it does not meet the exposure criterion (PM2.5). The study only examined PM10, NO2, and SO2, with no mention of PM2.5. Additionally, the outcome is respiratory mortality rather than respiratory hospitalization or ED visits as required by the inclusion criteria.

This study examines coarse particulate matter (PM2.5-10) as the primary exposure, not PM2.5. Additionally, the outcome is mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. While the study uses a time-series design and reports effect estimates, it fails to meet the inclusion criteria for both exposure (PM2.5) and outcome (respiratory hospitalization/ED visit).

Study examines PM10 (not PM2.5) exposure and mortality (not hospitalization/ED visits) as the outcome. The study meets criteria for being an original time-series study with effect estimates, but fails on two critical inclusion criteria: wrong exposure measure (PM10 instead of PM2.5) and wrong outcome (mortality instead of respiratory hospitalization/ED visits).

This study examines PM10 exposure (not PM2.5) and respiratory mortality (not hospitalization or ED visits). The outcome is deaths from respiratory causes, which does not meet the inclusion criteria requiring respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits as outcomes.

This study examines mortality as the outcome, not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. Additionally, the primary exposure is particle number concentration (PNC) and particle surface area concentration (PSC), not PM2.5. While PM10 is mentioned as a contrast pollutant, PM2.5 is not the main exposure of interest.

Study examines mortality as the outcome, not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. Additionally, the exposure is PM10 (not PM2.5), NO2, and O3. Fails to meet both the exposure criterion (PM2.5) and outcome criterion (respiratory hospitalization/ED visit).

This study fails to meet two critical inclusion criteria: (1) The exposure is PM10, not PM2.5, and PM2.5 is not mentioned as being analyzed in the study; (2) The outcome is mortality, not hospitalization or emergency department visits. While the study is a time-series analysis with quantitative effect estimates, the exposure and outcome do not match the review criteria.

Study examines PM10 exposure (not PM2.5) and cardiovascular outcomes (coronary heart disease hospitalization, not respiratory hospitalization). Fails to meet inclusion criteria for both exposure type and outcome.

The study outcome is mortality (all-cause, cardiovascular, and respiratory mortality), not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. Additionally, the primary focus is on economic losses rather than health outcomes, which does not align with the review's objectives.

The study examines coarse particulate matter (PM2.5-10), not PM2.5, as the primary exposure. Additionally, the outcome is respiratory mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. Both the exposure and outcome fail to meet the inclusion criteria.

While this is an original epidemiological study using case-crossover design with PM2.5 exposure and effect estimates, the outcome is mortality (cardiovascular, respiratory/thoracic cancer, all-cause) rather than respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits, which is required for inclusion.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. Additionally, the outcome is mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits as required by the inclusion criteria.

While this is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure with effect estimates reported, the outcome is mortality (deaths), not respiratory hospitalizations or emergency department visits. The study examines deaths and years of life lost from various causes including respiratory diseases, but does not assess hospital admissions or ED visits.

The outcome is mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visit. While the study examines PM2.5 exposure using a case-crossover design and reports effect estimates with confidence intervals, it does not meet the inclusion criterion for the outcome of interest (respiratory hospitalization/ED visit).

The outcome is mortality (all-cause mortality), not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. While the study meets other criteria (PM2.5 exposure, time-series and case-crossover design, quantitative effect estimates), the outcome does not match the inclusion criteria which specifically requires respiratory hospitalization/ED visits.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria explicitly require original epidemiological studies and exclude reviews and meta-analyses. Although the reviewed studies may have examined respiratory outcomes and used time-series designs, this publication itself is a synthesis of other studies rather than original research.

While this study meets several inclusion criteria (original epidemiological study, PM2.5 exposure, case-crossover design, reports effect estimates with CI), the outcome is respiratory MORTALITY, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits as required by the inclusion criteria.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria specifically require original studies and exclude reviews and meta-analyses. Additionally, the outcome is mortality rather than respiratory hospitalization or ED visits.

Although this is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure with quantitative effect estimates, the outcome is mortality (deaths), not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. The study examines respiratory mortality/deaths, which does not meet the inclusion criteria requiring respiratory hospitalization or ED visits as the outcome.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria specifically require original epidemiological studies and explicitly exclude reviews and meta-analyses.

While this is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure with quantitative effect estimates, the outcome is mortality (nonaccidental, cardiovascular, and respiratory mortality) rather than respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits as required by the inclusion criteria.

Although this is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure with quantitative effect estimates, the outcome is respiratory mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits as required by the inclusion criteria.

This is a multi-study initiative report that includes time-series epidemiologic studies of PM2.5, but the outcomes are primarily mortality and general morbidity rather than specifically respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. Additionally, it includes animal studies (mice) and in-vitro studies which are exclusion criteria. While one component (Ito study) mentions time-series epidemiology of morbidity, the abstract does not specifically identify respiratory hospitalizations as an outcome, nor does it report specific effect estimates for respiratory hospitalizations.

While this study includes PM2.5 as an exposure and uses time-series design, the outcome is respiratory mortality (deaths), not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits as required by the inclusion criteria. The study is also methodological in nature, comparing meta-analysis versus pooled analysis approaches, though it does appear to report effect estimates.

The study examines ozone exposure as the primary exposure (not PM2.5) and mortality as the outcome (not hospitalization or ED visits). While PM2.5 is mentioned as a covariate that was controlled for, it is not the main exposure of interest. The outcome is respiratory mortality, not respiratory hospitalizations or emergency department visits.

While this is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure with quantitative effect estimates, the outcome is respiratory mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits as required by the inclusion criteria.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis (not an original epidemiological study), and the outcome is heart failure hospitalization/incidence/mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. Fails inclusion criteria 1 and 3.

This is explicitly described as a review article in the abstract ('have been described in this review'). It does not report original epidemiological research or provide specific effect estimates from a primary study. The title 'Recent Insights' also suggests a review/overview format rather than an original study.

This is explicitly stated as a review ('In this review, we synthesize the scientific evidence'), not an original epidemiological study. It synthesizes findings from multiple studies rather than reporting original data. Reviews are specifically excluded per the exclusion criteria.

This is a scoping review, not an original epidemiological study. Additionally, the outcomes are neurologic diseases (stroke, dementia, Parkinson disease, MS) rather than respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. Fails inclusion criteria 1 and 3.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. It explicitly states 'This review aimed to systematically summarize the epidemiological literature' and describes searching and pooling results from 145 studies. Reviews and meta-analyses are explicitly listed in the exclusion criteria.

This is a review article (explicitly stated as 'This present review') focusing on biological mechanisms of PM2.5-induced cell death rather than an original epidemiological study. It does not examine respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits as an outcome, does not use time-series or case-crossover design, and does not report quantitative effect estimates like RR or OR.

This is a meta-analysis (not an original epidemiological study) examining the association between PM2.5 and myocardial infarction (MI), which is a cardiovascular outcome, not a respiratory hospitalization or ED visit. Fails inclusion criteria 1 (not original research) and 3 (wrong outcome).

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The first inclusion criterion requires original epidemiological studies, and the first exclusion criterion explicitly excludes reviews and meta-analyses. This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria explicitly require original studies and exclude reviews and meta-analyses.

This is explicitly stated as a review article ('The current review investigate epidemiological and experimental findings from 2016 to 2021'), not an original epidemiological study. This is explicitly described as a review article focusing on PM2.5 and chronic kidney disease, not an original epidemiological study. Additionally, the outcome is kidney disease rather than respiratory hospitalization or ED visits, which does not meet the inclusion criteria.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. It synthesizes findings from other studies rather than reporting original data. This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. Inclusion criterion 1 requires original studies, and exclusion criteria specifically exclude reviews and meta-analyses.

This study examines mortality as the outcome, not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. This appears to be a narrative review, commentary, or editorial discussing the general health effects of wildfire smoke and PM2.5 rather than an original epidemiological study. It does not describe a specific study design (time-series or case-crossover), does not report quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals, and reads as a general discussion of the topic with policy implications. The language used ('knowledge gaps remain', 'long-term research is essential', 'underscores the urgent need') is characteristic of commentary rather than original research.

This is a review article (explicitly stated as 'In this review, we summarize...'), not an original epidemiological study. The outcome focuses on vascular endothelial cell toxicity rather than respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. Does not meet inclusion criteria 1 (original study) or 3 (respiratory hospitalization outcome).

This is a rapid review/systematic review that synthesizes evidence from other studies, not an original epidemiological study. It explicitly states it used 'Cochrane rapid review methodology' and reviewed 450 manuscripts. Reviews are explicitly excluded per exclusion criteria.

This is a meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. Additionally, the outcome is respiratory disease mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits as required by the inclusion criteria.

The title explicitly indicates this is a review article ('A review of implications for human health'), not an original epidemiological study. This fails the first inclusion criterion. Additionally, the abstract describes general health impacts and does not report specific quantitative effect estimates (RR, OR) for the association between PM2.5 and respiratory hospitalizations.

This is a review article (as stated in the abstract: 'This review summarizes and discusses studies...') examining the association between PM2.5 and Alzheimer's disease/dementia outcomes, not respiratory hospitalizations. It fails to meet multiple inclusion criteria: it is not an original epidemiological study, the outcome is neurological (AD, dementia) rather than respiratory hospitalization/ED visits, and it is a review rather than a primary study.

This is a meta-analysis (not an original epidemiological study) examining cardiovascular outcomes (myocardial infarction) rather than respiratory hospitalizations. Fails inclusion criteria 1 (must be original study, not review/meta-analysis) and 3 (outcome must be respiratory hospitalization/ED visit).

This is a systematic review (not an original epidemiological study) examining the association between air pollution and ocular surface diseases (conjunctivitis, dry eye, blepharitis), not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. It fails multiple inclusion criteria.

This is a review article focusing on cardiovascular effects and vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs), not an original epidemiological study. The outcome is cardiovascular/vascular disease, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. The abstract explicitly states 'In this review, we primarily focus on...' confirming it is not an original research study.

This article focuses on cancer outcomes rather than respiratory hospitalization/ED visits. The abstract describes exploration of PM2.5's relationship with cancer risks and mortality across multiple organ systems. Additionally, the language ('this article explores', 'concludes by proposing') and broad review nature suggest this is a narrative review or commentary rather than an original epidemiological study with time-series or case-crossover design.

This is a review article (clearly stated in title and abstract), not an original epidemiological study. The outcome is cardiac developmental toxicity/congenital heart defects, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. Does not meet inclusion criteria for study type or outcome.

This is explicitly a review article focused on in vitro and in vivo experimental studies, not an original epidemiological study. It does not meet the inclusion criterion #1 requiring an original epidemiological study, and it meets the exclusion criterion for reviews. Additionally, it does not use time-series or case-crossover design, does not report specific effect estimates for respiratory hospitalizations, and focuses on animal/laboratory studies rather than human epidemiological data.

This is a review article, not an original epidemiological study. The abstract explicitly states 'This review aims to summarize and discuss the association...' Reviews are explicitly excluded per the inclusion criteria. Additionally, the outcomes focus on post-transplant complications (organ rejection, cardiovascular disease, infection-related mortality, vitamin D deficiency) rather than respiratory hospitalizations/ED visits.

This is a review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. Additionally, the outcome is mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. The study design appears to be long-term cohort studies, not time-series or case-crossover.

This appears to be a narrative review or commentary article rather than an original epidemiological study. The language 'This article discusses' and the focus on mechanisms and preventive measures indicate it is not presenting original research. Additionally, the primary focus is on cardiovascular disease (as stated in the title), not respiratory hospitalizations specifically. The study design cannot be determined as time-series or case-crossover from the abstract.
